abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Andhra Pradesh Irrigation
            Project had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that enabling policies and institutional
            changes are key for improved irrigation service delivery.
            Involvement of project beneficiaries groups is key to create
            ownership of project interventions and their sustainability.
            Longer term support to Water Users Associations (WUAs) is
            required for the capacity building and their sustainability.
            Early identification and close monitoring of key project
            activities  are critical for timely completion of the
            project. Complementing irrigation improvement with strong
            agriculture support services from project inception is key
            to maximize project benefits and promote sustainability.
            Simplification of procurement processes within the
            government is key to timely award and completion of project
            activities. Timely implementation of land acquisition and
            Resettlement and Rehabilitation (R&R) is a prerequisite
            for scheduled completion of project. Effective coordination
            between Irrigation and command Area Development Department
            (I&CADD) and Department of Agriculture (DoA) is critical
            for improving the performance of irrigated agriculture.
